characters: MOMENT THEN ABRUPTLY DROPPING OUT OF FRAME.
CAMERA PUSHES INTO THE PORTHOLE WINDOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FLIES OVER the "Welcome to Couer d'Couers" sign at the field's edge to FIND a bright, care-free boy of about (YOUNG NED) racing through the flowers sending petals fly as he chases his dog DIGBY, an adorable yellow lab as bri and care-free as Young Ned. Our OMNISCIENT NARRATOR (imag Patrick Stewart reading a bedtime story) begins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this very moment in the town of  Couer d'Couers, Young Ned was 9 years,  27 weeks, 6 days, and 3 minutes old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned is only a few feet behind his dog, 3 sets of le speeding through the brush. He reaches out trying to make contact, but Digby is just out of touch. Closer... closer The brush gives way to a clearing. Closer... closer, stil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His dog Digby was 3 years, 2 weeks,  6 days, 5 hours and 9 minutes old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM. Out of nowhere, Digby is HIT BY A PASSING SEMI-TRUC A BLUR OF BIG RIG obscures the impact. Ned stops, horrifi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not a minute older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME SLOWS TO A CRAWL. FUR SAILS THROUGH THE AIR, as if D was taking flight by his own propulsion. ALL SOUND DROPS except for the RAPID, RHYTHMIC POUNDING of Ned's HEART an the EXPANSION AND CONTRACTION of his LUNGS. He approaches the unmoving body of his dead dog Digby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was the moment Young Ned realized  he wasn't like the other children.  Nor was he like anyone else for that  matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned kneels down beside Digby and as he reaches out to str the dog's matted fur... CAMERA JUMP CUTS TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ridges of his fingertip look like circular troughs. A Ned touches his dog we see a small STATIC POP OF ELECTRIC between his finger and Digby's fur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME RESUMES TO NORMAL as Digby inexplicably scrambles to his feet with a happy dog-smile on his face and runs off  into the field of daisies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned could touch dead things  and bring them back to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned watches slack-jawed and furrow-browed as Digby  disappears over the horizon. He stares at his finger, not sure exactly what just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It lands on a cupboard door and darts to and fro until SM A FLY SWATTER ends its life in one abrupt movement. We ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dead fly lands on the counter top. Young Ned's MOTHER sets the fly swatter down and returns to lovingly prepari a pie, pressing dough into the pie plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a gift given to him, but not  by anyone in particular. There was  no box, no instructions, no  manufacturer's warranty. It just  was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned peers over the edge of the counter, reaching in and touching the dead fly. There's a small ELECTRIC POP t the fly flies up and out the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The terms of use weren't immediately  clear nor were they of immediate  concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS THE FLY and Young Ned's gaze to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl named CHUCK, pig-tails et al, plays in the back ya

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned was in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's making a small village out of mounds of dirt and  cardboard boxes with Play-Doh people and toy cars as her  FATHER waters the lawn in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name was Chuck. At this very  moment, she was 8 years, 42 weeks, 3  hours and 2 minutes old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She squeezes a little people head out of the Play-Doh Fun Factory and places it on the body she's already construct

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned did not think of her as  being born or hatched or conceived  in any way. Chuck came ready made  from the Play-Doh Fun Factory of  Life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes the final few touches on her village and it COM TO LIFE THROUGH THE MAGIC OF IMAGINATION.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGINATION REALIZED
dialogues.text: Large as life, TOY CARS drive through tiny streets, and T PEOPLE mill about on tiny sidewalks. BOOM. BOOM. BOOM. BOOM. The ground SHAKES. The TOY PEOPLE react to the strangeness... then a GIANT REPTILIAN LEG ST into a cardboard building, crushing it. CAMERA REVEALS A GIANT PIG-TAILED GODZILLA stomping throu the village, sparing no one as PLAY-DOH PEOPLE SCRAMBLE. And just when we think a lone TOM CRUISE-ESQUE PLAY-DOH P has escaped... SQUISH. A GIANT RODAN-ESQUE WINGED DINOSAU looking as much like Ned as the Godzilla looks like Chuck (wearing the same clothes, etc.) stomps him good.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH BACK TO REALITY
dialogues.text: Chuck and Ned are stomping through the remains of her sma village, having an absolute ball and getting very dirty.

dialogues.speaker: ON NED
dialogues.text: His Mother is sweeping the dirt off of him with a broom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freshly broomed, Young Ned stares out the window as filth Chuck is getting hosed off in the backyard by her Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was under Chuck's spell... until  a blood vessel in his mother's brain  burst, killing her instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned turns away from the window to find his Mother d on the linoleum floor next to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned reaches into FRAME and touches his Mother's che just below the eye. A BOLT OF STATIC ELECTRICITY. Her  constricted pupil dilates and Ned's Mother blinks. DING. The timer goes off.

dialogues.speaker: ON NED
dialogues.text: He slowly backs away as his Mother stares at him. A CLOCK appears in the corner of the OUR SCREEN and begins counti down from ONE MINUTE. 59 seconds... 58... 57...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned's random gift that was  came with a caveat or two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the timer go off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned nods as his Mother gets to her feet, brushes of her apron and pulls on a pair of OVEN MITTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must've slipped. Clumsy. Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned sits at the kitchen table, unable to look away as his Mother pulls a pie out of the oven. 37 seconds... 36... Ned's Mother places the pie in the kitchen window to cool

dialogues.speaker: ON CHUCK IN HER YARD
dialogues.text: She kicks over the last standing building and runs inside her Father continues to water the lawn in the background. The COUNTDOWN continues... 23... 22... 21...

dialogues.speaker: ON NED AND HIS MOTHER
dialogues.text: Ned watches as his Mother readies a second pie to go into the oven. 11... 10... 9... 8...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a gift that not only gave...  it took.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned's Mother twists the timer around, puts a new pie in t oven and as she closes the oven door. The CLOCK HAND has  traveled almost full circle: 4... 3... 2...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned discovered he could only  bring the dead back to life for one  minute without consequence. Any longer  and someone else had to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INCLUDE THE KITCHEN WINDOW, through which we can SEE Chuc Father drop dead. Young Ned and his Mother don't immediat see this because their backs are to the window. Ned's Mother cuts a piece of pie, puts it on a plate, and sets it down in front of Young Ned. He takes a bite. Heav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the most delicious pie ever  baked because it was the pie that  was not meant to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Mother's GASP draws his attention to the window, wher they can see Chuck's Father dead in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned stares out the window at an AMBULANCE slowly pulling  away from Chuck's house without its lights on, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned realized somehow in the  grand universal scheme of things, he  had traded his mother's life for  Chuck's father's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, big daddy, into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he was horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned's Mother pulls up the blankets so Ned can slide into  bed. She draws the blanket up to his chest. (NOTE: Never  touching him directly.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there was one more thing about  touching dead things that Young Ned  didn't know. And he learned it in  the most unfortunate way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves to kiss Ned on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they're about to make contact with his forehead, we se STATIC POP OF ELECTRICITY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned's Mother drops dead right then and there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First touch, life. Second touch,  dead again forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned kneels next to his dead mother, poking her cheek, wai for her to open her eyes again. She doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned sits on the porch, dressed all in black. He wat as Chuck's 30-something Grey Garden-esque aunts (VIVIAN a LILY) drag large steamer trunks into Chuck's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck was orphaned when her father  died and fostered by her aunts Vivian  and Lily. A renowned synchronized  swimming duo, they shared matching  personality disorders and a love for  fine cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned watches as his FATHER fills a steamer trunk wit all the belongings from his room, his Rodan costume,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For all intents, Young Ned was  orphaned, too. After a brief mourning  period, his father panicked at raising  a child alone. In the wake of that  panic, Ned was hustled off to boarding  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JEWISH and CHRISTIAN GRAVEYARDS are two halves of the same cemetary. The Synagogue and Church on either end of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hillside graveyard. Two funerals are taking place, one on each side of the graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At their respective parent's  funerals...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peak of the cemetary hill. Young Ned and the Neighbor Girl ENTER FRAME from their respective side, silhouetted the sun. She takes his hand and kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...dizzy with grief, curiosity and  hormones, Young Ned and a girl named  Chuck had their first and only kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Young Ned watches the Neighbor Girl head back down the hi After a moment, Young Ned's dog Digby returns and bounds  right up to Ned. He reaches out to pet Digby and the dog  pulls away. Despite this, Digby wags his tail and smiles, keeping a safe distance. As Young Ned leads Digby down th other side of cemetary hill, CAMERA BEGINS TO PULL BACK..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The effect of his Mother's death on  Ned's psyche was twofold. He avoided  social attachments, fearing what  he'd do if someone else he loved  died.  Secondly, he became obsessed  with pies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The setting sun shining bright and round MORPHS INTO A GO BROWN PIE on a cloud-print tablecloth. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 19 years, 34 weeks, 1 day and  59 minutes later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on a cooling window, the shelves lined with the  cloudprint tablecloth. On a pillow on the floor, is DIGBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Ned has become "The Pie-Maker,"  owner and pastry chef of "The Pie  Hole."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FINDS a PAIR OF HANDS rolling and kneading dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expression "pie in the sky"  entered popular culture in 1911,  referring to a dessert so sweet it  can only be found in heaven. But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charming Parisian (in tone)/American (in style) googiee bakery. The front of the business is rounded and given th facade of a giant pie wedged into the ground floors of an ADJACENT APARTMENT BUILDING, complete with a pie-crust ro A sign reads: The Pie Hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if you crave something before you  die I recommend where the Pie Maker  makes his pies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PUSHES IN ON the back of the Pie Maker as he works lining the pie pan with dough, not yet showing his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peaches never brown. Berries  ripe as the instant they were plucked.  If they weren't so delicious and  eaten so quickly, folks might notice  the pies stayed fresh an unusually  long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead, dying or bruised fruit is lovingly picked from a bo and placed into the empty pie crust. Bruises fade and dea fruit spontaneously engorges with juice, ripe and tasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because the Pie Maker  personally touches the contents of  every one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piece of NOW FRESH fruit spills out of the pie crust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dead fruit in his hands becomes  ripe with ever-lasting flavor -- as  long as he only touches it once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pie-Maker's hand snatches it before it hits the floor and the fruit spontaneously shrivels and darkens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For this reason, the Pie-Maker is a  vegetarian.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FINALLY REVEALS NED'S FACE
dialogues.text: Simultaneously handsome and awkward, about 30 years of ag Ned's lips are whistling but we don't hear a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bakes alone, whistling quietly to  himself, rarely pursing his lips  tight enough to produce a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Digby cocks his head, listening to what no one else can h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich and textured, like the inside of a pie. Tufted booth and a rounded counter bar (with spinning stools) that cur parallel to the pie facade exterior. Right out of the 40' The place is dappled with customers and a single WAITRESS CAMERA FINDS OLIVE, a 20-something waitress waiting on re customer EMERSON, a late 30's/early 40's African-American man in a seersucker suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day I come in, I pick a pie  and concentrate all my love on that  pie.  If I love it, then someone  else will love it. And you know what?  By the end of the day I've sold more  of those pies than any other pie in  the bakery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What pie do you love today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhubarb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stick with three plum. Ala mode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson Cod, soon to be enjoying a  slice of three plum pie ala mode,  was the sole keeper of the Pie Maker's  secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMERSON chases a RUNNING MAN across a rooftop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how he came to be the sole keeper  of the Pie Maker's secret...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Running Man jumps to make it to the next building and misses, plunging 10 stories to his death. Emerson looks o the ledge to see the Running Man HIT a trash bin with a B CRUNCHING WHAM that most definitely killed the man.  But BOUNCES into a SLIGHTLY YOUNGER NED who happened to be  emptying the trash at the time. CAMERA JUMPS TO AN EXTREME-EXTREME-EXTREME CLOSE UP of th impact and we SEE the POP OF STATIC ELECTRICITY. CAMERA POPS WIDE as the Dead Running Man OPENS HIS EYES a takes off again. Slightly Younger Ned gives chase. Emerson watches as Slightly Younger Ned tackles the Runni Man and he goes limp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the runaway corpse, Emerson  Cod, a Private Investigator, proposed  a partnership with the Pie Maker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PUSHES IN ON Emerson staring, slack-jawed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murders are much easier to solve  when you can ask the victim who killed  them.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Ned watches Emerson through the porthole window in the ki door. Emerson looks up from his pie. Their eyes connect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since the bakery was on the verge of  financial ruin, the Pie Maker agreed  so he could keep his Pie Hole open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's after hours and the bakery is closed. Blinds are dra over the windows and the lights are dim. As CAMERA FINDS and Emerson sitting at a booth speaking in hushed tones. Ned, forever the handsome, articulate recluse, fidgets a  bit, uncomfortable in his own skin. Digby sits nearby  listening to them MID-CONVERSATION:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you not to use the word  "zombie."  It's disrespectful.  Stumbling around, squawking for  brains. That's not how they do. And  "undead?" Nobody wants to be un- anything. Why begin a statement with  a negative? It's like saying "I don't  disagree." Just say you agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you comfortable with "living  dead?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned shakes his head for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're either living or you're dead.   When you're living, you're alive.  When you're dead, that's what you  are. And when you're dead and then  you're not, you're alive again. Can't  we say "alive again?" Doesn't that  sound nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you're a narcoleptic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suffer from sudden and  uncontrollable attacks of deep sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Necrophiliac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Words that sound alike get mixed up  in my head. Used to think masturbation  meant chewing your food. Now are you  interested in this opportunity or  not? (off his hesitation) A dog is involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at Digby) What kinda dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna be a dead dog. A dead dog named  Cantaloupe. Putting her down.  Allegedly killed her owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you say allegedly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cantaloupe was framed. Someone put  part of the victim in her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Docile as a kitten, says the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson holds up a picture of the dog, a chow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite it being a chow -- the breed  most likely to turn on its owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's racial profiling. Looky here,  if the dog's innocent, it's murder.  If it's murder, then there's a reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The facts were these: one Leonard  Gaswint, 39 years, 42 weeks, 5 days,  3 hours and 26 minutes old, was found  mauled to death in a parking garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chow named Cantaloupe cleans himself next to a parked c which partially obscures Leonard Gaswint's corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His dog Cantaloupe was the soul  witness and only suspect in the  murder.

dialogues.speaker: A REWARD SIGN
dialogues.text: There's a business photo of Leonard Gaswint with text tha reads: "REWARD $20,000."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convinced of her innocence, the  Gaswint family offered a significant  reward to find the real killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cantaloupe sits alone in her cell, awaiting execution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and Emerson stand outside the morgue with the CORONER who is filling out a series of forms on a clip board. TWO COUNTY SHERIFFS stand nearby, looking official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the dog expert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already had a dog expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the, uh... other one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson and Ned approach a sheet-covered body on a slab. Ned peeks under the sheet and Emerson takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's he look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks fine, but my threshold is  pretty high so you have to take what  I say with a grain of salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson takes a peek under the sheet himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a grain of salt. It's one  of those blocks they give cows to  lick.  The man's tore up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't help the way he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make it any less traumatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. And I'm sure him. But mainly me.   I'm fine when they don't move. It's  when they move that I have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it help if I turned off the  light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned turns off a metal floor lamp next to the drawer, cast a shadow over the body and obscuring it. Emerson pulls ba the sheet and reacts to the OFF-CAMERA corpse, mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned watches as Emerson quickly disappears out the door. A Ned's about to touch dead Leonard Gaswint's hand... CAMER JUMPS TO AN EXTREME-EXTREME-EXTREME CLOSE UP and we see t FAMILIAR POP OF ELECTRICITY. Ned sets the alarm on his wa A CLOCK appears in the corner of the SCREEN and begins  counting down from ONE MINUTE. 59 seconds... 58... 57... Leonard Gaswint sits upright into the light revealing he' been MAULED. He couldn't be nicer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Sorry to disturb you, Mr. Gaswint.   Or Leonard. Do you prefer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo. Your, um, current condition...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned indicates the missing part of Gaswint's face. The clo continues to count down: 43... 42... 41...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have something right here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There's nothing right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cantaloupe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Cantaloupe's docile as a  kitten.  It was that rottweiller. My  secretary sicked her dog on me. She's  been upset since last year's Christmas  party. You know, it's a funny story...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Gaswint can start, Ned touches him and life slips  from his body instantly. He stops his watch at 27 seconds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coroner and the Two Sheriff Deputies stand outside, a before, alone with Emerson. Ned steps out of the morgue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it the chow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secretary. With a rottweiler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cantaloupe bounds out of her kennel and down the aisle, h fellow kenneled dogs barking M.O.S. in support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECRETARY and the ROTTWEILLER are escorted out of her  apartment building, surrounded by MEDIA and POLICE.  CAME PULLS BACK TO REVEAL the image is on TV. We are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CONTINUES PULLING BACK TO REVEAL Olive sitting in over-stuffed lounge chair, Digby squeezed in next to her, his head on her lap. They're watching the evening news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anonymous tip led to solving the  murder of a Michigan entrepreneur  believed to have been fatally mauled  by a family pet. The truth, however...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KNOCK-KNOCK. Someone's at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive opens the door to find Ned standing on her stoop.   Digby pokes his head out from around the lounge chair. Th NEWSCASTER continues to prattle on in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your convention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws close to him, flirtatious and almost slightly  desperate for him to seduce her. He doesn't engage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conventional. How was Digby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neurotic. He's a very needy dog.  Do  you pet him? Maybe if you pet him  once in a while he wouldn't be so  neurotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned steps inside and around Olive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pet him. I'm allergic so I can't  actually touch him. But I pet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a stick? How do you pet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stick is involved, but it's more  like a handle to a... petting device.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog needs to be touched. We all  need to be touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You touch him. Other people touch  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your dog. Do you touch anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I... I touch lots of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With affection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches out and touches his shoulder, holding her han there an uncomfortable beat. Ned innocently averts his ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time someone touched  you with affection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds his gaze for another uncomfortable moment. He c his throat, she finally pulls back her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get Digby's leash? (to Digby) You don't mind that I don't touch  you, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Digby smiles and wags his tail, happy to see Ned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then came the event that changed  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned's attention is drawn away from Digby and to the telev news broadcast. A NEWSCASTER reports:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other news, the body of a young  woman allegedly murdered aboard a  cruise ship was recovered from the  sea. Her identity is being held  pending notification of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned watches on the television as an image of a LIMP, LIFE WOMAN is hauled out of the water by a system of pulleys o the deck of the cruise ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pie-Maker listened intently to  the news, unaware that he stopped  breathing.  He was haunted by the  nameless woman who met her end on  the high seas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive approaches with Digby's leash in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he didn't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Ned, totally rapt, ignoring Olive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned has one eye on the pies he's making and the other on small television set in the corner of his kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name still withheld, very little  is known of the victim, who was  reportedly traveling alone when ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned gives Digby a scratch with the petting device.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...murdered aboard a passenger ship  returning from a tropical cruise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned looks up from the television to see Emerson through t porthole window in the kitchen door -- he's seated at a b in the restaurant. Their eyes connect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's after hours and the bakery is closed. Blinds are dra over the windows and the lights are dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been watching the news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't seem like much is going on  in the world besides a dead girl on  a boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot's going on with that dead girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm. 100,000 dollars of that's  so.  Interested in a conversation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could be persuaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better be persuaded quick cause  dead girl's about to go in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just pulled her out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewish. Christians leave 'em laying  around. Jews gotta get 'em buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coeur d'Coeurs. Ever been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up there. Sort of. (lost, then:) So this dead Jewish girl from Coeur  d'Coeurs. She have a name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POW. He might as well have punched Ned in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Young Chuck stomping through the dirt city in her yard -- Young Chuck and Young Ned at Halloween. She's Godzilla he's Rodan, they hold their candy bags out for goodies. -- Young Chuck and Young Ned kissing in the graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and Emerson sit opposite each other next to a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know of her in the biblical sense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't thought of her since I was  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of her a lot when you were 10?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't remember anything when I was  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pie-Maker remembers everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA IS ANGLED UP at the undulating surface of the wate SPWOOSH. A BODY breaks the surface in a cloud of bubbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The facts were these... Charlotte  Charles, 28 years, 24 weeks, 3 days,  11 hours, and 51 minutes old, was  found floating in the ocean moments  after her body was discarded there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silhouette of dead Charlotte Charles floats in the su

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Discarded by whom seemed to be a  question only Charlotte Charles could  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple, pine casket. The lid is set in place over  Charlotte's beautiful, lifeless body. We don't see her fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewish law prescribes burial in a  plain white shroud to demonstrate  equality for all. No bling. For this  reason...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FUNERAL DIRECTOR, a chain-smoking obese man, stands  outside the Home as MOURNERS file inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the nondenominational Funeral  Director preferred non-Jewish  services.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE LAVISH COFFINS
dialogues.text: -- The Funeral Director opens the coffin lid and pulls th NECKLACE off of a DEAD WOMAN'S neck. -- ...pulls the WATCH off a DEAD MAN'S wrist. -- ...pulls the SIZEABLE RING off a DEAD WOMAN'S finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Funeral Director continues to watch MOURNERS file in. CAMERA FINDS Ned and Emerson approaching in the throng of mourners. Emerson begrudgingly slips the Funeral Director some cash, he quickly pockets it and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The simple, pine casket in the middle of the room surroun by much fancier coffins. The afternoon sun shines through window -- a light on the pine casket. Emerson and Ned ENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I just wanna... I wanna... Can't  I do this one alone? On account of,  you know, the whole historical  context?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got something personal you wanna  say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Okay, perhaps. I have nothing to  gain but a small amount of closure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha'cha got so open it needs closing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanna say I'm sorry for  something.  One of those stupid things  kids do... that they don't know  they're doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask who killed her first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only got one minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson walks out eyeing Ned, who closes the door behind  him. Alone in the room, Ned braces his back on the door a takes a deep breath. Gulp. He slowly approaches the caske Ned runs his hand over the pine frame then lifts the lid, bathing the body of Charlotte Charles, aka CHUCK, in sunl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Prince Charming could know how  the Pie-Maker felt upon looking at  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even in death she's beautiful, a woman yet very much the  little girl he once knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great thought was taken as to where  to touch her. The hand too impersonal,  lips too forward, the cheek... the  cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned's finger closes in on Chuck's alabaster cheek and CAM JUMPS TO AN EXTREME-EXTREME-EXTREME CLOSE UP of his slow  caress. A CRACKLE OF ELECTRICITY between finger and cheek A CLOCK appears in the corner of the SCREEN and begins  counting down from ONE MINUTE. 59... Chuck opens her beautiful eyes and blinks. Ned can only s back at her. The moment is as electric as his touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her, expecting a warm smile in return but  instead... WHAM. She grabs him by the jacket and SLAMS HI HEAD between the coffin and its lid. WHAM-WHAM-WHAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck scrambles out of her coffin as Ned stumbles back in daze. She grabs a chair and raises it to hit him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck! Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember the little boy who  lived next door to you when your dad  died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We used to destroy small villages  together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck stares at him a moment... confused... then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned? Hey. How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finally puts the chair down. 46... 45... 44...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. You look great. Um, do you  know what's happening right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had the strangest dream I was being  strangled to death with a plastic  sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a dream. You were...  strangled to death with a plastic  sack. That's probably an odd thing  to hear but I wasn't quite sure how  to sugar-coat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a moment. She glances at her burial shroud, her  coffin and finally the viewing room filled with caskets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh. And I'm...? Neat. How...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only have a minute. Less. About  38 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. What can I do in 38 seconds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell me who killed you so,  um, you know, justice can be served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so sweet. I just wanna put  you in my pocket. But I don't know  who killed me. I went to go get ice.  I was filling my bucket and I dropped  my room key in the ice maker and  just as I was thinking that was  dumb...

dialogues.speaker: ACTION
dialogues.text: CHUCK stands at the ice machine perplexed with a bucket o ice under her arm. FWIP - a bag is thrown violently over head. She sucks air and it shrink-wraps to her face. The ice tumbles to the deck in the FOREGROUND as Chuck is murdered in the BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...then you touched my cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEEP-BEEP-BEEP: Ned's watch alarm goes off. 15 seconds le

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my time up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Chuck was just starting to get used to being alive ag It's weird and sad, but all she can think to say is:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for calling me Chuck. Nobody's  called me Chuck since... you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson RAP-RAP-RAPS on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you beeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Chuck back in her coffin, Ned holding the lid. 11... 10.. He stumbles on his words, trying to speak but overwhelmed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to say I'm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at her, Ned can't bring himself to tell her he  inadvertently killed her father. So instead he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to... when I lived next door  to you... I had a cru... I was in...  You were my first kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, touched) You were my first kiss, too. Or did  you think I'd been around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to assume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna be my last kiss? First and  last?  Or is that weird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not weird. It's symmetrical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5... 4... He looks at her and slowly moves in for the kis She closes her eyes. Their lips are about to connect when

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Funeral Director scoots into the stall, pulling down pants, sitting on the toilet and striking up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Ned and Chuck, their lips hang in the air, centimeters ap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lips went as far as they would  go.  He couldn't will them to go any  further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck opens her eyes. 2... 1... Minute's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then THUNK -- we HEAR The Funeral Director's life head hit the stall door. Then the smoking cigarette drops

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Ned slowly pulls away from Chuck, who lies there blinking He let her live and someone else died, the weight of it a is clearly on Ned's face when he looks back at Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't wanna kiss me, you  don't... It was just a... I thought  it might...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I want to, I do... I... What if  you didn't have to... be dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that would be preferable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAP-RAP-RAP, Emerson pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody can know. I have to think  about how to get you outta here. Can  you lay really still until I get  back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sure --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she can finish, he's closing the coffin lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned emerges from the viewing room, quickly shutting the d behind him. He's nervous and a little sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know. Didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone tossed her carcass off a  boat and -- why are you sweating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm -- it's warm in there. What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your eye's twitching. When people  aren't telling the truth, their eye  twitches.  Right there. Like yours  did, just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nerves. Aggravated by a stomach  thing. Like acid reflux but in my  eye.  I think I'm gonna stay for the  service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling nostalgic. I'll catch a later  train. Remember how to get to the  station? It's down the, uh... Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned runs in and STARTLES at an ELDERLY JEWISH MAN standin next to where Chuck's coffin was but no longer is. The El Jewish Man STARTLES, as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... uh, where's the deceased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to an open back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone to sleep with her fathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm sor -- You sort of mumbled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's getting buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Ned's ohshit of it all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HEARSE is pulling away as Ned BURSTS out of the doors the Funeral Home in PANICKED HOT PURSUIT. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned runs across the cemetery vaulting over headstones. He cuts into a road and falls into step behind the Hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned chases the hearse until he disappears in a cloud of d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned waves at the clouds of dust. He sees the Hearse conti down the driveway until it turns onto the street, a long  line of cars pull out behind it. Ned sees which direction the Hearse is heading and cuts a the Funeral Home yard, jumping over fences and hedges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small amount of light coming through the joints of th coffin barely illuminates Chuck. She's beaming, awestruck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Sleeping Beauty could know how  Chuck felt at this moment. With a  brush of his finger across her cheek,  the world became a place of magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck is suddenly JOSTLED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then the pallbearers pulled her  out of the hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 PALLBEARERS pick up the casket and carry it out the bac door following the RABBI walking ahead of them. The  Pallbearers are unevenly matched -- tall on one side, sho on the other -- consequently there's some slippage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck continues to be jostled about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pallbearers stop and we HEAR Chuck slide up and bump head on the inside of the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Pallbearers react to the "Ow," glancing at one anothe over the top of the casket, each thinking it was the othe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned runs as fast as he can, spying the cemetery up ahead. He quickens his pace, running past the last of the mourne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck lies there, waiting patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying in the dark, Chuck considered  how she came to be lying in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PUSHES IN ON YOUNGER VIVIAN AND YOUNGER LILY, thei backs to us as they sit on the side of the pool facing ve very sparsely populated audience stands, mermaid fins cov their legs. A SIGN READS: "The Darling Mermaid Darlings."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She considered the life that was  with Aunts Lily and Vivian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yard is over-run with growth and the paint is peeling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No longer nursing at the teat of  synchronized swimming stardom, their  personality disorders blossomed into  incapacitating social phobias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIVIAN (early 50's) is cleaning a birdcage. LILY (early 5 dressed in a kimono and an eyepatch) shields her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which made it difficult for them to  leave the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL... they're surrounded by DOZE AND DOZENS of CAGED BIRDS in a maze of STACKS AND STACKS newspapers and magazines. Chuck is moving through the hou opening curtains and windows and allowing fresh air to fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which in turn made it difficult for  Chuck to leave them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck is wearing a bee keeper's outfit and pulling cells honeycomb out of the hive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She never strayed far from home. She  served the community by harvesting  honey in her backyard...

dialogues.speaker: ON A HOMELESS MAN
dialogues.text: He's below a banner reading: "HONEY FOR THE HOMELESS: HON DRIVE." Chuck stands next to him holding a jar of honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chuck sits in the window sill reading a novel, the emp shelves in the room FILL WITH BOOKS until the walls are  "literally" covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and read about people she could  never be, on adventures she would  never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck ENTERS glancing around at all the promise of advent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life was good enough until one day...   it wasn't. Chuck wanted more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHUCK'S P.O.V. as she approaches the smiling MANAGER DIED next to giant STANDEE advertising a TAHITIAN CRUISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The irony that her want for life got  her killed was not lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA ROCKETS through the headstones until FINDING a lar mound of earth next to a hole in the ground next to a  headstone that reads "Charles Charles, Loving Father." Th TWO GRAVEYARD WORKERS seen earlier are about to take thei first shovels-full of dirt and sling them into Chuck's gr Ned runs up to the Graveyard Workers, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I think somebody's truck's on  fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look over his shoulder to see their work truck CONSU IN FLAMES. The Workers GASP and run to put out the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy -- Oh, jeez --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned makes sure they're not looking and jumps into the gra pulling the lid off the coffin. Chuck sits up and smiles the sight of her Prince Charming. He returns the gesture:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck and Ned sit at a booth, Chuck wrapped in his coat. watches her devour a piece of pie and a large glass of mi Ned is still filthy from digging up her grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even hug you? What if you  need a hug? A hug can turn your day  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a fan of the hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you haven't been hugged properly.   It's an emotional Heimlich. Someone  puts their arms around you, gives a  squeeze. All your fear and anxiety  comes shooting out of your mouth in  a big, wet wad and you can breath  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine for someone else to do,  if I'm choking. On something other  than emotion. But you can't touch  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So a kiss is out of the question. (off his look) I'm teasing. I'm teasing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost my train of thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the most delicious pie I've  ever tasted... you use a lot of  butter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head, then touches a piece of fruit that's  fallen out of the pie, it SHRIVELS before our very eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never had so much in common with a  pie. (back to point) Why didn't you touch me twice? I  haven't seen you in 20 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a very good memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long were you thinking about  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like thinking-thinking? It wasn't  premeditated.  I wasn't lying in  wait.  More like I was musing on the  idea.  Not, you know, dwelling. But  I wasn't seriously considering until  the exact moment I did it. Or, um,  didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck stares at him a moment -- this is all overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wondered if you'd come back.   I guess you came back when I needed  you most. Well, that would've been  before I was killed but this worked  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand you can't go back,  right?  You can't see your aunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're shut-ins, it's not like they  talk to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People aren't used to this sort of  thing.  Issues of morality and "how  come she's not dead anymore?" It'd  be a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose dying is as good excuse as  any to start living my own life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you're not the only Jew  whose ever risen from the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am if you asked a Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and Chuck stand in front of Digby, who wags his tail. It's clear from Ned's slouching that he's exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Digby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't your old dog named Digby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he...? Did you...? And now  he's...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to do that a lot. Why do  you do that a lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just the two of you. I don't  mean to be a bad host but I'm sort  of exhausted from chasing your coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned crosses to the couch and lays down, dirt and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna sleep here, you take the  bed.  I insist. My eyes are rolling  back into my head. I'm laying down  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ned is already sound asleep. He snores quietly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I'd kiss you if it wouldn't kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck sits up in bed, watching the TELEVISION NEWS. A can "while living" PICTURE OF CHUCK's smiling face looms over NEWSCASTER #1'S shoulder as he recites the news:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 year-old "Lonely Tourist" Charlotte  Charles was laid to rest earlier  today --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a strange bed watching her own  funeral on the evening news, Chuck  was struck by the undignified nature  of celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time she CLICKS the remote the NEWSCASTER changes b her haunting "while living" picture stays the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A passenger heard a commotion just  moments before the victim's body  fell past his window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe her death should be celebrated.   If she hadn't died, she wouldn't  have this chance to finally live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boutique Travel travel boutique has  offered a 100,000 dollar reward for  the murderer of customer Charlotte  Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck reacts, no one said anything about a reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned sleeps on the couch. CAMERA SLOWLY REVEALS Chuck sitt on the big wing-back chair opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I be alive right now if I knew  who killed me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Don't be silly -- That's  a -- Something on the news about the  reward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you wanted to know who killed  me so justice could be served. But I  don't think justice was on the menu.   Maybe as a side dish. But not an  entree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It most certainly was an entree. It  was a special of the d -- Can we  drop the metaphor? I wouldn't have  known you died if it weren't for the  reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When were you gonna tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the morning or when it came up.   Which ever didn't come first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100,000 dollars makes a lotta pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 thousand. I have a business  partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in the traditional sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You touch murder victims, ask who  killed them, touch 'em again, they  go back to being dead and you collect  the reward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... that's it in a nutshell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you after my reward? I'm not mad  at ya, I just wanna know. I'll be  mad at ya if you lie to me, though.  Is that why you're keeping me around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want your reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be so mad if you're lying. You'll  have me scratching the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not lying. Please don't attack  the window treatments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck stands and returns to the bedroom. Ned lays his hea back down on the couch, unable to shut his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck in bed, facing the living room. She closes her eyes and reaches out and puts her palm to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...on the other side. He reaches out and touches the wall He and Chuck appear to be holding hands side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck opens her eyes to find a note taped to the lamp sha It reads: "Please do NOT leave this apartment."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck, in long coat, scarf and sunglasses, turns and is  surprised to see Olive standing outside her apartment  surprised to see a woman coming out of Ned's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a friend of Ned's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olive sizes her up for a moment, then out of curiosity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he touch you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson sits opposite Ned before the bakery is open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was the service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, just paid my respects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't looking to get paid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might see a dead woman speaking to  you in confidence as an opportunity  to make a whole lot of money by your  lonesome.  Regardless of prior  arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no opportunity here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, Chuck slides into the booth next to Emerson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Are you the business partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte Charles. Call me Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson can only stare. Ned buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been ruminating. And by  ruminating I mean pondering, not  chewing cud. How about we solve my  murder and collect the reward.  Wouldn't that be poetic?  It's  certainly an anecdote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's supposed to be in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chuck) I thought you didn't want the reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I wanted you not to want the  reward.  100,000 dollars is a lot of  money. How about a 3 way split?  30/30/40? Only fair I get more. I  did die for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a detective. I make pies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just touch somebody's life  and be done with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I can. That's how I roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For someone who brings people back  to life, you're awfully dead inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned reacts to that, stung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do 30/30/40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's supposed to be dead. (to Chuck) You're supposed to be dead. I think  this is pushing your luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, luck pushed me first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Chuck's determination...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson and Ned on the googie-esque pie crust roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just so shockingly stupid I  have a hard time believing you did  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just agreed to be her partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to profit from your  stupidity.  Are you in love with  her? Cause it's that level of stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll admit to being confused. This  is a very confusing time. Childhood  issues.  Diggin' in the dirt. S'all  coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have the childhood issues. I  got a full subscription. Horror  stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kinda killed her dad when I was  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not "horror" stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know. I wanted to make  it better or different from what it  was because what it was was her dead  and I didn't want that to be my fault,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who died instead, Captain Sav'a'ho?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned hands him the folded newspaper in his back pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a random proximity thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch, I was in proximity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson glances at the obituaries and a circled picture o the now deceased obese, chain-smoking Funeral Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered where he went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank god he was an A-hole. He took  stuff off of dead people and sold it  on ebay. It's all in the obituary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice. Fact he was an A- hole make you feel better about what  you did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Immensely. I would've felt  horrible if it was... you, for  example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson slaps Ned upside the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow. I'm not proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that you did it. Makes the  worst thing I ever did seem  insignificant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to you all judgey-judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know this woman. You don't  know anything about her. Except she  got herself killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ned takes that in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pie-Maker hadn't considered Chuck  could be anything but the little  girl next door he fell in love with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA DRIFTS OVER THE LEDGE to find the side of the Pie  Hole Bakery, moving through a window and into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She only ever had charitable thoughts  and her heart was filled with  kindness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FINDS Chuck sitting at the booth alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was who he wanted her to be and  no one else... until proven otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and Emerson slide into the booth next to Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not who you think I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson gives Ned a side-long glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who does he think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small town girl who never saw  the world only to have her first  time out be her last. Well, that is  who I am but I've been hoisted upon  my own petard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a petard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my case, a petard is the wander- lust that compromised my judgment.  That Tahitian getaway was a devil's  bargain.  And the devil... was Diedre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diedre Duffield holds the door open for Chuck as she ENTE Once inside, Diedre locks the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diedre Duffield was the local manager  of Boutique Travel travel boutique  who lured Chuck with the promise of  a highseas adventure at no cost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I had to do was pick up a package  for Diedre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a drug mule?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm a monkey mule. I met a man  in a park and he gave me a brief  case.

dialogues.speaker: BRIEF CASE
dialogues.text: A stainless steel Halliburton molded in an alligator prin The case opens to REVEAL a pair of PLASTER MONKEY STATUES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You died for a pair of plaster  monkeys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diedre said their value was  sentimental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those must be some emotional monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, clearly he didn't want to  part with them. You should ask Diedre  about all of this. I'm very curious  what she has to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK FROM Diedre the Boutique Manager to REV she's SPEAKING M.O.S. in front of SEVERAL REPORTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The facts were these: in a shrewd  marketing ploy, the Boutique Travel  travel boutique offered a 100,000  dollar reward in the death of  Charlotte Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson, Ned and Chuck pull up in front of the building. Only Ned and Emerson get out. Chuck slouches in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boutique Travel travel boutique  manager, Diedre Duffield, hoped it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: would catch a killer before a killer  caught her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and Emerson open the door. They step inside and a bel CHIMES. The store appears to be empty, they look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Anybody home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned looks around as Emerson goes into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson ENTERS and stops short at strangled-to-death Died sitting at the break table, plastic bag over her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although on-line sales increased by  23 percent, the reward fell short of  achieving its desired goal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he ENTERS) This is really no way to run a --  Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck is now staring at Diedre's  dead body along with Ned and Emerson.  Chuck carefully pulls the bag off  her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I can't be too mad at  her. Is that how they found me? That's  humiliating. She looks horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how long she's been here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch the poor bitch and ask her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates, to Chuck) I'm sort of embarrassed to do it in  front of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck turns around and Ned touches Diedre. A familiar POP ELECTRICITY. Diedre opens her eyes, blinks and sits up. glances around, more than a little confused -- wasn't she just murdered. She locks eyes with Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOCK appears in the corner of the SCREEN: 59... 58...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Diedre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why'd I know you'd be the first  person I'd see when I got to... is  this... which one is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't either. Or maybe it's  both.  But here's the deal: you get  to talk for like a minute so we're  gonna catch up. Then you're... not  talking anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does everybody get to do this? Cause,  girl, we got to break it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know I was gonna get killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it might be a possibility.   And I'm real sorry about that. I  probably should have said something.   But to be honest, and really? Why  not at this point? If it was safe, I  would've done it myself. This is  fantastic. Being honest is fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck is stunned. The clock continues: 34... 33... 32...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Chuck) Ask who the dude was that killed  you.  And her. And what's with the  monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Ned and Emerson) Um, who are those people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Emerson. I don't know him  really.  And this is Ned. He was my  first kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, now he's adorable. Look at this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diedre reaches over and pinches Ned's cheek and THUNK! He head hits the table as she goes back to being dead INSTAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't have taken a step back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know she was gonna pinch my  cheek. Who does that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She... actually, she does that a  lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever killed you, killed your girl  Diedre as evidenced by the plastic  sack.  But why would whoever killed  you kill her if he already got his  monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dropped my key in the ice maker.  He couldn't get in my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLASTIC SACK KILLER, his face OUT OF FRAME, stands ou a cabin door holding dead Chuck slumped over in his arms, he fumbles through her bathrobe for her room key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for Pete's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries the handle, it doesn't open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have the monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get murdered on a boat,  where do they send your stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your next of kin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I got killed for the monkeys and  Diedre got killed for the monkeys  then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA VERY QUICKLY PULLS BACK TO REVEAL we're in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has been stripped of all personal belongings. Th briefcase sits on a bed, surrounded by STACKS OF BOOKS. I fact, the whole room is filled with STACKS OF NEWSPAPER. CAMERA CONTINUES PULLING BACK INTO...

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: ...and down the stairs to the:

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Vivian is preparing a cheese platter while Lily watches a old television playing a NEWSREEL of the DARLING MERMAID  DARLINGS in action, swimming in circles under water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Aunt Vivian and Aunt Lily who  received custody of the monkeys. And  they were about to be paid a visit  by the man willing to kill for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DING-DONG. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that, would you dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned's VINTAGE MERCEDES screeches to a halt across the str from Chuck's Aunts' House. Ned, Emerson and Chuck hop out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanna look in the windows.  Like the ghost of Christmas past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't your Christmas anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my pie and I wanna eat it,  too.  I'll get crumbs in the bed I  don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't. You can have your pie,  but you can't eat it. That's how it  works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck was the Pie-Maker's pie and he  could never have a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if something happened?  What if  they got hoisted on my petard, too?  I would just die. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could give you an emotional  Heimlich so you could cough up that  wad of fear and anxiety, but... I  can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned stares at her, his heart swells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Emerson) Give her a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson gives Chuck a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck watches them cross the street to her Aunts' house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For 19 years, 33 weeks, 3 days, 7  hours and 42 minutes, Aunt Vivian  and Aunt Lily were all Chuck had.  And before Chuck, all they had were  each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teen Vivian and Lily loll underwater, rolling over and ov languidly in sea-shell bikini tops and mermaid fin bottom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They made a name for themselves as  the "Darling Mermaid Darlings."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teen Vivian and Teen Lily dive, pivot, shoot out of the w and flip, perfectly synchronized. The CROWD goes wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30's VIVIAN and LILY loll underwater, rolling over and ov less gracefully than before, their mermaid fins not as cu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still holding onto their fading glory  as under-water artists, their lives  were changed forever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES PAST an advertisement for the "Darling Merma Darlings" to FIND 40's Lily cleaning the litter box as th cat waits patiently for her to be done. She accidentally  flips cat sand in her own face and recoils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...when Lily cleaned the litter box  and got dirty cat sand in her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cat now sits at the edge of the pool watching 30's Vi and 30's Lily (with an eye patch) loll underwater with no indication of grace, colliding into each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only was the eye lost but their  careers, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CROWD in the stands is only 7 percent of what it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Chuck and 30's Vivian and 40's Lily lead a RABBI an train of PALLBEARERS carrying her father's coffin through the GRAVEYARD on the hill above the Synagogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They retreated behind a fence and  made sure the world stayed on the  other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivian is preparing a cheese platter while Lily watches a old television playing a NEWSREEL of the DARLING MERMAID  DARLINGS in action, swimming in circles under water. DING-DONG. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that, would you dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and Emerson stand at a walk-in gate talking to a box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Uh, my name is Ned. I lived next  door 20 years ago. I was a friend of  Chuck's... or Charlotte's, rather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson shoots him a look. BUZZZ. The walk in gate unlatc and Ned turns and gives Chuck in the car a thumbs up. She returns the thumbs up and then immediately scrambles out the car, running to catch the gate before it closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned and Emerson sit opposite Vivian, they're surrounded b CAGED BIRDS of all varieties and a maze of newspaper stac As Vivian sets a sad cobbled-together cheese and cracker  plate in front of their guests, Lily prattles on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte was a firecracker. Always  trying to get us out of the house,  threatening to bake anti-depressants  into our food. Got to the point I  was scared to eat anything she cooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a good cook. And a nice girl.   Do you like girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte was a nice girl.  With the  exception of puberty. Which was  unfortunately the same time Lily was  going through her change of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impolite to discuss a person's  menopause in mixed company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It nearly killed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily turns the subject back to Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrible the way Charlotte died. On  a cruise. Last days spent surrounded  by middle-aged over-weight women who  wear sweatshirts with things sewn to  them.  Usually kittens made of felt.  And the food is perfectly atrocious.  Unless she enjoyed vomiting and  diarrhea, I can't imagine she had a  good last meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good last meal goes a long way.  Our penal system makes a point of  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice she had a little glimpse  of the world before she died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world isn't that great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least she had the sense not to  fly.  Airplanes fall outta the sky  every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheese? I recommend the pure goat  with blue ash. Has a grassy flavor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerson takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does have a grassy flavor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's delicious with Charlotte's honey.   You haven't lived until you've tasted  her honey. The homeless love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds off emotion) We'll never taste her honey again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck peers through the window at her Aunts, examining th life she left behind. Regardless of their neurosis, Chuck Aunts were the only family she had and she loves them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the life of her, Chuck couldn't  remember why she was so desperate to  leave her Aunts behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned reacts as he catches Chuck peering through the window He tries not to lose his focus and keep on task:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to change the subject, but has  the cruise line returned her  belongings?  Specifically a stainless  steel briefcase?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck spots Ned spotting her and ducks out of sight. She sneaks another look at her Aunts through the window,  surrounded by their feathered friends in cages. She moves around the side of the house, eyes the stacks of bee hive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
